sec.p: Verbena officinalis L. classified in Verbenaceae family is commonly known as vervain. It is natively grown in Europe. Verbena has been traditionally used in herbalism and folk medicine, as herbal tea. Among other effects, it may act as a galactagogue and possibly sex steroid analogue. Verbena has been listed as one of the 38 plants used to prepare Bach flower remedies [ 46].

Several researches reported the antimicrobial activity of vervain EO and investigated that this activity could be related to the high amounts of monoterpenes and phenolic compounds. In fact, the major constituents of this EO were o-cymene, isobornyl formate, citral, carvacrol, and thymol [ 19]; further details of the main components of vervain EO have been reported in Table 2.
